Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: They are overseeing a crowded beach during high tide, where one moment of inattention could put multiple swimmers at serious risk.
Story: I stood at my lifeguard post, eyes scanning the churning waves and the clusters of swimmers bobbing in the high tide. The whistle hung heavy around my neck, a constant reminder that every second counted. My phone buzzed in my pocket—another message from my stepmom, asking if I was coming to the family holiday picnic. My dad had already called twice, reminding me how important it was to show up, to be part of the family, especially since things were still new between us all. I could picture them setting up the grill, my little stepsister waiting for me to join the games, everyone hoping I’d finally fit in. But here, on this crowded beach, I was the only lifeguard on duty. If I left, even for a short while, I’d be letting down everyone who trusted me to keep them safe. The pressure built inside me—torn between the family that wanted me present and the strangers who needed me vigilant. I stared at the waves, heart pounding, caught between two worlds that both demanded all of me.
